Full Statement: Child manages emotions with increasing independence
Calms when held by a familiar caregiver
Smiles or vocalizes in response to familiar voices.
Initiates simple interactions, like holding hands.
Seeks adults for comfort during challenges
"Child can identify and articulate their own emotions."
"Child utilizes appropriate coping strategies to handle negative emotions."
"Child independently resolves emotional distress or conflict, and can return to play or tasks."
PreK Learning Outcomes (2020 Edition) (PreK 48-60) Learning Outcome
Child follows classroom rules and routines with increasing independence
Shows recognition of familiar routines through calmness or anticipation
Participates in simple routines, such as putting toys in a bin when encouraged.
Begins anticipating steps in routines, like washing hands before eating.
Participates in group routines, such as lining up or cleaning up toys
Adaptability to changes in rules and routines
PreK Learning Outcomes (2020 Edition) (PreK 48-60) Learning Outcome
Applies Classroom Rules in Daily Routine
Child appropriately handles and takes care of classroom materials
Grasps and explores objects with curiosity.
Begins to place items in designated spaces with guidance.
Helps with simple clean-up tasks, such as putting books back on a shelf.
Begins to understand the value of taking care of shared materials.
Child demonstrates understanding of rules for using materials
Child actively participates in the cleaning and return of materials
Child displays awareness of classmates' use of materials
PreK Learning Outcomes (2020 Edition) (PreK 48-60) Learning Outcome
Child manages actions, words, and behavior with increasing independence
Reacts to caregiver’s facial expressions and calming voice
Begins to stop or start actions based on simple verbal cues.
Uses simple words to express needs or feelings instead of actions (e.g., “Mine!”).
Demonstrates self-control during transitions and group activities.
Child can complete age-appropriate tasks with little to no assistance (Self-sufficiency).
Child demonstrates control over emotions and can communicate feelings appropriately (Emotional regulation and communication).
Child follows rules and instructions, showing an understanding of appropriate behavior (Understanding and adherence to rules).
PreK Learning Outcomes (2020 Edition) (PreK 48-60) Learning Outcome
Child demonstrates an increasing ability to control impulses
Waits briefly when attention is redirected.
Pauses actions when a caregiver says “no” or redirects.
Attempts self-control with gestures or words (e.g., waiting before grabbing a toy).
Controls impulses with guidance, such as refraining from interrupting.
Child shows improvement in delaying immediate gratification for a bigger reward.
Child increasingly adheres to set rules and boundaries, demonstrating enhanced self-discipline.
Child often utilizes problem-solving strategies instead of acting on initial impulses.
PreK Learning Outcomes (2020 Edition) (PreK 48-60) Learning Outcome
Child maintains focus and sustains attention with minimal adult support
Watches moving objects or faces for short periods.
Focuses on activities, such as stacking blocks, for increasing durations.Engages with a single activity for a few minutes before seeking adult interaction.
Resumes tasks after mild distractions, such as looking back at a toy after hearing a noise.
Completes multi-step tasks with reminders (e.g., “Pick up the block and put it in the bin”).
Child engages with a single activity for an extended period (5-10 minutes) without frequent redirection.
Child follows simple instructions and completes short tasks with minimal reminders from adults.
Child shows interest and curiosity by asking questions and exploring materials independently.
PreK Learning Outcomes (2020 Edition) (PreK 48-60) Learning Outcome
Attempts to grasp objects or roll over, even after initial failure.
Seeks adult assistance if unable to complete a task independently.
Tries multiple approaches to solve problems, such as stacking blocks after a tower falls.
Uses trial-and-error methods without giving up quickly.

Child holds information in mind and manipulates it to perform tasks

Completes familiar sequences, like stacking blocks in order, using memory.

Task Execution is observed informally or formally.

The child is able to differentiate between various objects and phenomena based on their observable characteristics such as size, color, shape, and texture. This skill builds the foundation for making comparisons and distinctions between different phenomena.
Child sorts objects based on various criteria,

The child develops the ability to group similar objects and phenomena together based on their common features. They can sort objects into categories, such as animals and plants, or round and square objects.
The child starts to analyze and reason out the differences and similarities of objects and phenomena through keen observation.

Student uses critical thinking to analyze and interpret investigations.

Child can group objects or pictures based on shared characteristics.
Child can explain why they have grouped items in a particular way.

Child recognizes, duplicates, and extends simple patterns

Notices changes or repetitions in visual or auditory stimuli.
Attempts to mimic repeating movements or sounds.

PreK Learning Outcomes (2020 Edition) (PreK 48-60) Learning Outcome
Responds to predictable routines (e.g., quieting during feeding or diaper changes).
Attempts to repeat familiar order-based tasks, like putting objects back into a container.
Demonstrates emerging understanding of time-based sequences, such as “first snack, then nap.”
Follows simple multi-step directions in order, such as “Put your shoes away, then sit down.”
PreK Learning Outcomes (2020 Edition) (PreK 48-60) Learning Outcome
Domain #5: Perceptual, Motor, and Physical Development
Child demonstrates control, strength, and coordination of large muscles
Lifts head during tummy time and begins rolling over.
Crawls, pulls up to stand, and begins walking with support.
Walks steadily and runs with increasing confidence
Climbs stairs with alternating feet and jumps with both feet.
Child can successfully execute a range of activities exercising large muscles such as jumping, running, climbing, and balancing.
Child shows significant improvements in muscle strength and can effectively handle objects like balls, hoops, or bicycles.
Child exhibits coordinated movements in relation to spatial awareness, including maneuvering around obstacles.
PreK Learning Outcomes (2020 Edition) (PreK 48-60) Learning Outcome
Showcases upper body strength and control
Exhibits lower body strength and control
Child demonstrates coordination and balance in isolation.
Child uses perceptual information to guide motions and interactions with objects and other people
Turns head toward sounds or visual stimuli.
Tracks moving objects and adjusts body movements accordingly
Uses visual cues to adjust movements (e.g., stepping over obstacles).
Combines visual and tactile information to solve problems, such as fitting shapes into a sorter.
Child is able to appropriately adjust movements and responses based on perceived information, demonstrating control of over their actions.'
Child can accurately interpret visual, auditory, and tactile information to determine distance, location, and characteristics of objects and beings.'
Child can engage effectively in interactive activities by using perceptual cues to understand and respond to the actions of others.'

Strings large beads and manipulates puzzle pieces.
Child exhibits steady improvement in fine-motor tasks
Child displays growing strength in small muscle groups
Child demonstrates accurate handling and manipulation of objects

Child demonstrates personal hygiene and self-care skills
Reacts positively to being cleaned or cared for by caregivers
Begins to assist in basic self-care tasks, such as holding out arms to put on clothes.
Attempts simple self-care tasks with assistance, such as washing hands or using a spoon.
Independently completes basic tasks, like washing hands with supervision.
Child independently performs basic hygiene tasks such as washing hands, brushing teeth, and tidying up personal items.
Child understands the importance of a daily hygiene routine and can follow simple self-care instructions.
Child recognizes the need for cleanliness and is able to identify when personal care, like using the restroom or cleaning up a spill, is needed.

Understands simple safety instructions, like "Stop" or "No."
Begins to follow basic safety routines, such as holding hands while walking.
Anticipates safety rules during familiar routines, such as waiting before crossing the street.
Child can identify potential dangers in various environments (home, school, playground).
Child correctly follows personal safety routines like hand-washing, crossing the road, etc.
Child exhibits understanding of how to seek help from trusted adults in unsafe or uncomfortable situations.
